item.title: Jim Millstein Says US Risks ‘Fiscal Disaster’ If Recession Hits
item.description: Washington lawmakers are risking a “fiscal disaster” if a recession hits as they plow on with their package of sweeping tax cuts, according to Guggenheim Securities Co-Chair Jim Millstein.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

media:content.media:description: James Millstein, founder and chief executive officer of Millstein & Co., speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, U.S., on Thursday, Sept. 29, 2016. According to Millstein, slow growth and low interest rates drive down returns on pension funds, causing stress "anywhere we have large municipal and state governments" with unionized workforces.

item.title: Galipolo Vow on Higher-for-Longer Brazilian Rates Boosts Bets on Cycle’s End
item.description: Central bank President Gabriel Galípolo said Brazil needs interest rates to remain at a very restrictive level for longer, boosting investors’ bets that policymakers could stop the current tightening cycle at their next meeting in June.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andre Loureiro Dias

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Galipolo, governor of the Central Bank of Brazil, at the National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Galipolo is meeting with the Senate to discuss the ability to track irregular transactions, the possibility of implementing specific records for resource transfers involving the online gaming sector, and the assessment of the economic impact of betting on the financial system.

item.title: Ghana at Loggerheads With Afreximbank Over $768 Million Debt
item.description: Ghana, emerging from a bruising debt restructuring process, faces a dispute with African Export-Import Bank, one of its biggest commercial creditors, over whether it should take losses on a $768.4 million liability.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: Cassiel Ato Forson

item.title: Starmer’s Reset Hailed by EU Chiefs, Slammed by UK Conservatives
item.description: Keir Starmer sealed an agreement with European Union leaders that lays the ground for closer collaboration with the bloc, while revealing the political peril to Britain’s Prime Minister of revisiting the terms of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Antonio Costa, left, Keir Starmer, and Ursula von der Leyen on May 19. Photographer: Carl Court/Getty Images

item.title: Fed Officials Signal Possible Rate Hold Until at Least September
item.description: Two Federal Reserve officials, including New York Fed chief John Williams, suggested policymakers may not be ready to lower interest rates before September as they confront a murky economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: John Williams. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Jefferson Says Fed Policy in a ‘Very Good Place,’ Can Be Patient
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson said the central bank must ensure any price increases resulting from policy changes in Washington don’t lead to a persistent rise in inflation.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Philip Jefferson, vice chair of the Federal Reserve

item.title: Romania Budget Woes Put Brakes on Post-Election Market Rally
item.description: Romania’s assets rallied after a centrist candidate defeated his nationalist opponent in the presidential election, but further market relief may be limited until the next government presents a plan to fix state finances.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Peter Laca

media:content.media:description: A supporter holds a poster of Nicusor Dan in Bucharest, Romania, on May 18.

item.title: Chile Economy Kicked Off 2025 With Better-Than-Expected Growth
item.description: Chile’s economy expanded more than forecast at the start of the year as non-mining activity held up before global trade concerns came to the forefront.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

item.title: Brazil Economic Activity Still Hot as Hiking Cycle Nears Its End
item.description: Brazil’s economic activity outperformed expectations in March, underscoring the lingering challenges facing policymakers as they debate whether or not hit pause on their monetary tightening cycle.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of Brazil's central bank in Brasilia. Photographer: Andressa Anholete/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Must Be Cautious on Further Interest-Rate Cuts, Muller Says
item.description: The European Central Bank can’t rule out further reductions in borrowing costs but must be cautious as there’s no clear need yet to actively support economic growth, according to Governing Council member Madis Muller.
item.dc:creator: Ott Tammik, Mark Schroers

item.title: Fed’s Bostic Flags Inflation Concerns, Sees One Cut This Year
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic emphasized his worries over inflation as he repeated his expectation for one interest-rate cut this year.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic.

item.title: France Touts Record Foreign Investment at Macron’s Summit
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron will tally more than €40 billion ($45.1 billion) in foreign investment at an annual gathering with business leaders, seeking to send an upbeat message as the slow-growing economy faces headwinds from US trade tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Tara Patel, William Horobin, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron

item.title: Sell America Debate Back After Moody’s Downgrade
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics enterprise editor in Sydney. Today we’re looking at concerns over US debt sustainability and trade policy. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott, Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Stacks of $10 dollar notes move through a machine at the US Bureau of Engraving and Printing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 21, 2024. Money-market fund assets rose as elevated short-term rates continued to lure funds, even after recent economic data suggests the Federal Reserve could ease monetary policy this year.

item.title: Tariffs Emerge as a Fiscal Blind Spot in GOP Budget Debate
item.description: The Republican majorities in the US Congress are embroiled in a vigorous debate over the fiscal future of the world’s largest economy. But it’s a discussion that’s curiously avoiding one of the most consequential acts of fiscal policy the US has carried out in many years: Yes, the Trump tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: UK Home Asking Prices Rise to Record High Despite Tax Hit
item.description: Asking prices for UK homes rose to a new record high in May despite the drag on the real estate market caused by the end of a tax cut for buyers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Thailand Slashes Growth Forecast on Impact of Trade War
item.description: Thailand significantly lowered its forecast for economic growth this year as the global trade war undercuts private investment and exports, adding to already-weak consumption at home.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: Gold Markets Are Cited by ECB as a Risk to Financial Stability
item.description: Gold markets could be a source of danger to the euro zone’s financial stability in the event of geopolitical stress, the European Central Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at a precious metals refinery plant in Italy.

item.title: Euro-Area Inflation to Fall Below 2% on US Tariffs, EU Predicts
item.description: Euro-area inflation will fall below the European Central Bank’s target next year because of fallout from US trade policies, according to the European Commission.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) beyond containers at a freight terminal in Frankfurt.

item.title: China Consumption Miss Overshadows Factory Strength Amid Tariffs
item.description: China’s industrial output expanded faster than expected in April while consumption disappointed, highlighting the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy despite a quick de-escalation of trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang, Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: Photo by Costfoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: Japan Minister’s Brag About Free Rice Misfires Amid Surging Prices
item.description: Japan’s agriculture minister said he’d been inconsiderate after comments about his plentiful supply of free rice struck a nerve with the public, who face soaring prices in stores.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hilton

media:content.media:description: A customer shops for rice at a supermarket in Koshigaya, Japan.

item.title: China-US Tariff Truce Prompts Some Nations to Shift Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: IMF Tightens Conditions for Pakistan to Get Fresh Loans
item.description: The International Monetary Fund has tightened the loan conditions for Pakistan for future funding, and warned of risks to the South Asian nation’s economy from US President Donald Trump’s tariff policies and escalating tensions with India.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider

media:content.media:description: Customers browse for dry fruit inside the Empress Market building in Karachi, Pakistan, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Pakistan is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Dec 1.

item.title: African Central Banks to Join Emerging Market Peers Easing Rates
item.description: Central banks in key African economies are getting set to line up with other emerging-markets in coming weeks and cut interest rates where inflation pressures are seen abating, or stay on guard where the path is less clear.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

item.title: Thailand, Indonesia Pledge to Boost Trade as Strategic Partners
item.description: Thailand and Indonesia pledged to boost trade and investment and cooperate on cyber scam and drug trafficking crackdowns, as Southeast Asia’s two biggest economies elevated ties to a strategic partnership.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Prabowo Subianto, left, and Paetongtarn Shinawatra in Bangkok on May 19. Photographer: Lillian Suwanrumpha/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Ishiba Rebuffs Tax Cut Demands With Greek Debt Comparison
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba rebuffed calls for tax cuts saying that the nation’s financial conditions are worse than Greece’s.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Rafizi Says Johor-Singapore Zone to Remain Even if He’s Replaced
item.description: Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will remain a government priority as he sought to assure investors of the longevity of the program.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Rafizi Ramli Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Says Won’t Fixate on US Trade Talk Time Limits
item.description: Japan won’t compromise its national interests in trade talks with the US by fixating on time limits, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said, signaling Tokyo isn’t rushing into an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Anna Rose Layden/UPI

item.title: Japan PM Ishiba’s Support Falls, No Ouster Seen Before July
item.description: Support for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s government weakened, according to public opinion surveys published by major Japanese news organizations over the weekend, although it remains unlikely he’ll be ousted before a national election in July.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s Productivity at 60-Year Low as Reforms Selected
item.description: Australia’s Productivity Commission has identified 15 priority reforms to examine in the course of five inquiries it’s conducting for the government to try to boost economic efficiency and raise living standards.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Sydney Harbour, with the Sydney Harbour Bridge and buildings in the central business district (CBD).

item.title: Midpoint of Trump Tariff Hiatus to Reveal Increasingly Unsettled World
item.description: Reports in the coming week may give the fullest reading to date of how major economies are faring with trade disruptions, halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day hiatus on so-called reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn.
